natural problem: The area of a rectangle is 432 square centimeters. What would the new area be if the length of the rectangle was decreased by $10\%$ and the width of the rectangle was increased by $10\%$? Express your answer to the nearest whole number.
natural solution: If the length of the rectangle is decreased by $10\%$, it will be $90\%$ of what it was. If the width is increased by $10\%$, it will be $110\%$ of what it was. The area will be $0.9 \times 1.1 = 0.99 = 99\%$ of what it was.
Thus, $99\%$ of 432 is $0.99 \times 432 = 427.68$ or about $\boxed{428\text{ square centimeters}}$.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes area length width new_length new_width :: real
assumes h0 : "area = length * width"
and h1 : "new_length = 0.9 * length"
and h2 : "new_width = 1.1 * width"
shows  "new_length * new_width = 428"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The area of a rectangle is 432 square centimeters. What would the new area be if the length of the rectangle was decreased by $10\%$ and the width of the rectangle was increased by $10\%$? Express your answer to the nearest whole number. The final Answer is 428\text{ square centimeters}
 ### Proof
 If the length of the rectangle is decreased by $10\%$, it will be $90\%$ of what it was. If the width is increased by $10\%$, it will be $110\%$ of what it was. The area will be $0.9 \times 1.1 = 0.99 = 99\%$ of what it was.
 Thus, $99\%$ of 432 is $0.99 \times 432 = 427.68$ or about $\boxed{428\text{ square centimeters}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes area length width new_length new_width :: real
assumes h0 : "area = length * width"
and h1 : "new_length = 0.9 * length"
and h2 : "new_width = 1.1 * width"
shows  "new_length * new_width = 428"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Suppose the area of a rectangle is given by the product of its length and width. If the length of the rectangle is reduced by 10% to yield a new length, and the width of the rectangle is increased by 10% to yield a new width, then the area of the rectangle with the new length and new width is 428.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes l w :: real
assumes h0 : "l * w = 432"
and h1 : "(l - 0.1*l) * (w + 0.1*w) = new_area"
shows  "new_area = 428"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The area of a rectangle is 432 square centimeters. What would the new area be if the length of the rectangle was decreased by $10\%$ and the width of the rectangle was increased by $10\%$? Express your answer to the nearest whole number. The final Answer is 428\text{ square centimeters}
 ### Proof
 If the length of the rectangle is decreased by $10\%$, it will be $90\%$ of what it was. If the width is increased by $10\%$, it will be $110\%$ of what it was. The area will be $0.9 \times 1.1 = 0.99 = 99\%$ of what it was.
 Thus, $99\%$ of 432 is $0.99 \times 432 = 427.68$ or about $\boxed{428\text{ square centimeters}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes l w :: real
assumes h0 : "l * w = 432"
and h1 : "(l - 0.1*l) * (w + 0.1*w) = new_area"
shows  "new_area = 428"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: If the area of a rectangle is 432 square units, and both the length and width are adjusted such that the length is decreased by 10% and the width is increased by 10%, what is the new area of the rectangle? The final answer is 428 square units.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes area length width :: real
assumes h0 : "area = length * width"
and h1 : "length = length * 0.9"
and h2 : "width = width * 1.1"
shows  "area = 428"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The area of a rectangle is 432 square centimeters. What would the new area be if the length of the rectangle was decreased by $10\%$ and the width of the rectangle was increased by $10\%$? Express your answer to the nearest whole number. The final Answer is 428\text{ square centimeters}
 ### Proof
 If the length of the rectangle is decreased by $10\%$, it will be $90\%$ of what it was. If the width is increased by $10\%$, it will be $110\%$ of what it was. The area will be $0.9 \times 1.1 = 0.99 = 99\%$ of what it was.
 Thus, $99\%$ of 432 is $0.99 \times 432 = 427.68$ or about $\boxed{428\text{ square centimeters}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes area length width :: real
assumes h0 : "area = length * width"
and h1 : "length = length * 0.9"
and h2 : "width = width * 1.1"
shows  "area = 428"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: Find the original area of a rectangle if the length is reduced by 10% and the width is increased by 10%, resulting in a new area of 428 square units.

a_3.informal problem: A rectangle has an area of 432 square units. If the length of the rectangle is reduced by 10% and the width is increased by 10%, what would be the new area? The final answer is 428 square units.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes l w :: real
assumes h0 : "l * w = 432"
and h1 : "0.9 * l * 1.1 * w = new_area"
shows  "round new_area = 428"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The area of a rectangle is 432 square centimeters. What would the new area be if the length of the rectangle was decreased by $10\%$ and the width of the rectangle was increased by $10\%$? Express your answer to the nearest whole number. The final Answer is 428\text{ square centimeters}
 ### Proof
 If the length of the rectangle is decreased by $10\%$, it will be $90\%$ of what it was. If the width is increased by $10\%$, it will be $110\%$ of what it was. The area will be $0.9 \times 1.1 = 0.99 = 99\%$ of what it was.
 Thus, $99\%$ of 432 is $0.99 \times 432 = 427.68$ or about $\boxed{428\text{ square centimeters}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes l w :: real
assumes h0 : "l * w = 432"
and h1 : "0.9 * l * 1.1 * w = new_area"
shows  "round new_area = 428"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: A rectangle has an area of 432 square units. If the length is decreased by 10% and the width is increased by 10%, the new area is slightly less than the original. What is the new area, rounded to the nearest whole number? The final answer is 428.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes length width new_length new_width area new_area :: real
assumes h0 : "length * width = area"
and h1 : "area = 432"
and h2 : "new_length = length * (1 - 0.1)"
and h3 : "new_width = width * (1 + 0.1)"
and h4 : "new_length * new_width = new_area"
shows  "new_area = 428"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The area of a rectangle is 432 square centimeters. What would the new area be if the length of the rectangle was decreased by $10\%$ and the width of the rectangle was increased by $10\%$? Express your answer to the nearest whole number. The final Answer is 428\text{ square centimeters}
 ### Proof
 If the length of the rectangle is decreased by $10\%$, it will be $90\%$ of what it was. If the width is increased by $10\%$, it will be $110\%$ of what it was. The area will be $0.9 \times 1.1 = 0.99 = 99\%$ of what it was.
 Thus, $99\%$ of 432 is $0.99 \times 432 = 427.68$ or about $\boxed{428\text{ square centimeters}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes length width new_length new_width area new_area :: real
assumes h0 : "length * width = area"
and h1 : "area = 432"
and h2 : "new_length = length * (1 - 0.1)"
and h3 : "new_width = width * (1 + 0.1)"
and h4 : "new_length * new_width = new_area"
shows  "new_area = 428"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: A rectangle has an area of 432 square units. If the length is decreased by 10% and the width is increased by 10%, what is the new area of the rectangle? The final answer is 428 square units.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A :: real and L :: real and W :: real
assumes h0 : "A = L * W"
and h1 : "A = 432"
and h2 : "L = L - 0.1 * L"
and h3 : "W = W + 0.1 * W"
shows  "round (L * W) = 428"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The area of a rectangle is 432 square centimeters. What would the new area be if the length of the rectangle was decreased by $10\%$ and the width of the rectangle was increased by $10\%$? Express your answer to the nearest whole number. The final Answer is 428\text{ square centimeters}
 ### Proof
 If the length of the rectangle is decreased by $10\%$, it will be $90\%$ of what it was. If the width is increased by $10\%$, it will be $110\%$ of what it was. The area will be $0.9 \times 1.1 = 0.99 = 99\%$ of what it was.
 Thus, $99\%$ of 432 is $0.99 \times 432 = 427.68$ or about $\boxed{428\text{ square centimeters}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes A :: real and L :: real and W :: real
assumes h0 : "A = L * W"
and h1 : "A = 432"
and h2 : "L = L - 0.1 * L"
and h3 : "W = W + 0.1 * W"
shows  "round (L * W) = 428"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: A rectangle has an area of 432 square units. If the length of the rectangle is decreased by 10% and the width is increased by 10%, what is the new area of the rectangle? Round your answer to the nearest whole number. The final answer is 428.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A A' l w l' w' :: real
assumes h0 : "A = l * w"
and h1 : "l' = 0.9 * l"
and h2 : "w' = 1.1 * w"
and h3 : "A' = l' * w'"
and h4 : "A = 432"
shows  "round A' = 428"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The area of a rectangle is 432 square centimeters. What would the new area be if the length of the rectangle was decreased by $10\%$ and the width of the rectangle was increased by $10\%$? Express your answer to the nearest whole number. The final Answer is 428\text{ square centimeters}
 ### Proof
 If the length of the rectangle is decreased by $10\%$, it will be $90\%$ of what it was. If the width is increased by $10\%$, it will be $110\%$ of what it was. The area will be $0.9 \times 1.1 = 0.99 = 99\%$ of what it was.
 Thus, $99\%$ of 432 is $0.99 \times 432 = 427.68$ or about $\boxed{428\text{ square centimeters}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes A A' l w l' w' :: real
assumes h0 : "A = l * w"
and h1 : "l' = 0.9 * l"
and h2 : "w' = 1.1 * w"
and h3 : "A' = l' * w'"
and h4 : "A = 432"
shows  "round A' = 428"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: Given a rectangle with length $l$ and width $w$ that has an area $A = 432$ square units. If the length is reduced by 10% to $l' = 0.9l$ and the width is increased by 10% to $w' = 1.1w$, what is the area $A' = l' * w'$ of the new rectangle? Give your answer rounded to the nearest whole number. The final answer is $428$.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes area length width :: real
assumes h0 : "area = length * width"
and h1 : "length > 0"
and h2 : "width > 0"
and h3 : "length' = 0.9 * length"
and h4 : "width' = 1.1 * width"
shows  "(round (length' * width')) = 428"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The area of a rectangle is 432 square centimeters. What would the new area be if the length of the rectangle was decreased by $10\%$ and the width of the rectangle was increased by $10\%$? Express your answer to the nearest whole number. The final Answer is 428\text{ square centimeters}
 ### Proof
 If the length of the rectangle is decreased by $10\%$, it will be $90\%$ of what it was. If the width is increased by $10\%$, it will be $110\%$ of what it was. The area will be $0.9 \times 1.1 = 0.99 = 99\%$ of what it was.
 Thus, $99\%$ of 432 is $0.99 \times 432 = 427.68$ or about $\boxed{428\text{ square centimeters}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes area length width :: real
assumes h0 : "area = length * width"
and h1 : "length > 0"
and h2 : "width > 0"
and h3 : "length' = 0.9 * length"
and h4 : "width' = 1.1 * width"
shows  "(round (length' * width')) = 428"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: A rectangle has a length and width such that both are positive and the area is the product of the length and width. Now, the length is reduced by 10% and the width is increased by 10%. What is the area of the new rectangle, rounded to the nearest whole number? The final answer is 428.

fixes l w :: real
assumes h0 : "l * w = 432"
and h1 : "l' = l * 0.9"
and h2 : "w' = w * 1.1"
shows  "round (l' * w') = 428"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem

 *)

theorem
fixes l w :: real
assumes h0 : "l * w = 432"
and h1 : "l' = l * 0.9"
and h2 : "w' = w * 1.1"
shows  "round (l' * w') = 428"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: A rectangle has an area of 432 square units. If the length is reduced by 10% and the width is increased by 10%, what is the new area of the rectangle, rounded to the nearest whole number? The final Answer is 428.
